block.p: As president of the 1,450-member American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery (Asaps), the leading organization of surgeons who specialize in cosmetic surgery and who are certified by the American Board of Plastic Surgery, I want to commend Anne Jarrell for her article ''Doctors Who Love Publicity.''

As president of the 1,450-member American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery (Asaps), the leading organization of surgeons who specialize in cosmetic surgery and who are certified by the American Board of Plastic Surgery, I want to commend Anne Jarrell for her article ''Doctors Who Love Publicity.''

The Asaps Code of Ethics states clearly that no member shall give anything of value to a representative of the media in anticipation of or in return for professional publicity unless the fact of compensation is made known in such publicity.

Unfortunately, people interpret the mention of a physician in the media as an endorsement, and the media often lead readers/viewers to conclude that these procedures are safe no matter who is wielding the instrument.

Prospective patients should check credentials, making sure that their doctors have the training for the procedure they are considering and that any facility in which surgery is performed is accredited.
DANIEL C. MORELLO, M.D. New York
